intro: Phyllanthus chamaecristoides subsp. chamaecristoides, commonly known as the narrow-leaf phyllanthus, is a shrub native to tropical and subtropical regions of Africa and Asia. It typically grows to a height of 1–2 meters, featuring opposite, lanceolate leaves with a slightly hairy surface. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in clusters, followed by small, capsule-like fruits containing numerous seeds. It is often found in disturbed soils and can thrive in full sun to partial shade. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological and horticultural studies.
